subject: Re: [junit] Adding NotImplmented interface to JUnit
msgSnippet: Hi, ... To bring in another view of ignored/unimplemented test cases in here: I generate many parts of my code from UML2 models using templates (JET templates
messageBody:
Hi,

>>As opposed to simply prepending a character or string to the test
>>name, which would hide it from JUnit?
> I suppose it depends on intent. The JUnit-addons test runner reports
> "ignored" tests without actually executing them. Some people might find
> that valuable in general, although I suppose in this case, it may not be
> all that useful.

To bring in another view of ignored/unimplemented test cases in here:

I generate many parts of my code from UML2 models using templates (JET
templates of the Eclipse Modeling Framework). Also tests are generated.
Sometimes I can just generate interfaces or abstract classes and also
just tests stubs.

At the moment my Test classes contain tests like:

public testSomething()
{
fail("Please implement!");
}

That show at least what is working. But it hides the information about
if there was a real problem or not. Since I generate for a legacy system
I implement only needed parts of generated interfaces or abstract
classes. For thus I implement the tests.

I could change the template to generate testSomething_ignored(). But JET
can merge java code an it would detect that the *_ignored tests is
missing in the case of regeneration.

So in that situation it would be helpful to do something like:

public testSomething()
{
notImplemented("Please implement!");
}

Every implemented test would fail/error or pass. All other would claim
that I have to implement them. I could miss to implement tests for some
code, but I would always see if code with existing tests is broken.

regards.
--
Alexander Rupsch
http://www.dreinhalb.de
